greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Rewrite the binary expansion of n from the most significant end, 1 -> 1, 0+1 (one or more zeros followed by one) -> 0, drop the trailing zeros of the original n.
example: 102 in binary is 1100110, we rewrite it from the left so that first two 1's stay same ("11"), then "001" is rewritten to ""0, the last 1 to "1", and we ignore the last 0, thus getting 1101, which is binary expansion of 13, thus a(102) = 13.
program: (Scheme): (define (A209859 n) (let loop ((n n) (s 0) (i (A053644 n))) (cond ((zero? n) s) ((> i n) (if (> (/ i 2) n) (loop n s (/ i 2)) (loop (- n (/ i 2)) (* 2 s) (/ i 4)))) (else (loop (- n i) (+ (* 2 s) 1) (/ i 2))))))
xref: This is an "inverse" of A071162, i.e. a(A071162(n)) = n for all n. Bisection: A209639. Used to construct permutation A209862.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Mar 24 2012
